docs.lead_paragraph: A French Muslim who attacked a male gynecologist for examining his wife in a hospital delivery room just after a complicated birth, saying it was against Islam, has been jailed for six months by a Paris court. The police had to intervene to remove the 23-year-old man, who said he had requested a female doctor. ''This is a public and secular place,'' a prosecutor, Georges Holleaux, said. ''This is not the place where one can invoke religion to get different treatment.''

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: France: Muslim Jailed For Attacking Gynecologist

docs.lead_paragraph: A health foundation created by New York State announced its first grants yesterday, devoting considerable attention to obesity and resulting problems like diabetes, and to asthma. It also addressed other ills as disparate as alcohol abuse and lack of dental care.

headline.main: Weight and Diabetes Are Focus of Health Foundation Grants

docs.lead_paragraph: A young couple persists in making a new path for their own children.

headline.main: Two Who Were in Foster Care Make Providing Stable Home a Priority
headline.print_headline: Two Who Were in Foster Care Make Providing Stable Home a Priority

docs.snippet: A young couple persists in making a new path for their own children.

keywords.value: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Stephanie Robinson Davis and Randy Davis are young parents just starting out. There can be a lot to learn, but in the Davises' house, they already know that their children come first. ''I try my best to give them everything I didn't have,'' said Mr. Davis, 27. ''I want them to have a stable home. I never really had a stable home because I was in and out of foster care.''

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Two Who Were in Foster Care Make Providing Stable Home a Priority

docs.abstract: Stephanie Robinson Davis and Randy Davis receive help with family expenses from Children's Aid Society, beneficiary agency of New York Times Neediest Cases Fund; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration asked a panel of experts on Tuesday whether it should require new contraceptive drugs to meet a standard of effectiveness before approving them for sale.

headline.main: New Rules for Birth Control Are Examined
headline.print_headline: New Rules for Birth Control Are Examined

docs.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration asked a panel of experts on Tuesday whether it should require new contraceptive drugs to meet a standard of effectiveness before approving them for sale.

docs.lead_paragraph: The government is considering raising standards for birth control drugs, saying new pills appear to be less effective at preventing pregnancy than those approved decades ago. The Food and Drug Administration asked a panel of experts on Tuesday whether it should require new contraceptive drugs to meet a standard of effectiveness before approving them for sale. The panel is to meet again on Wednesday.

headline.main: New Rules for Birth Control Are Examined

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration is considering raising standards for birth control drugs, saying new pills appear to be less effective at preventing pregnancy than those approved a decade ago, most likely because manufacturers have started using lower doses of hormones that stop ovulation; says newer pills have twice the failure rate at times (S)
